[Statement 1]: There is limited research specifically addressing the cost-effectiveness of different methods for controlling problematic plants on peatlands.
[Statement 2]: Cutting or mowing herbaceous plants shows some effectiveness.
[Statement 3]: A replicated study in Sweden found that mown plots contained more fen-characteristic plant species than unmown plots.
[Statement 4]: Cutting large trees or shrubs can increase species richness and cover of fen-characteristic plants.
[Statement 5]: Cutting large trees or shrubs can increase moss and vascular plant cover and richness.
[Statement 6]: Physical removal of problematic plants showed mixed results in three replicated studies in fens.
[Statement 7]: One Irish study reported increased cover of fen-characteristic plants after mossy vegetation was removed.
[Statement 8]: The effects of removing mossy vegetation varied by species, site, and drainage conditions.
[Statement 9]: Herbicide application to shrubs was evaluated in one replicated, controlled study in fens.
[Statement 10]: Herbicide application changed plant community composition.
[Statement 11]: Herbicide application could not prevent increases in shrub cover over time.
[Statement 12]: The database lacks specific cost-effectiveness comparisons between control methods for peatland plants.
[Statement 13]: The database lacks economic analyses for peatland plant control specifically.
[Statement 14]: No studies were found that directly compared the costs and effectiveness of different control methods on peatlands.
